Award.AwardTitle: Impact, Cavitation and Fracture of Polymers with Liquid-Filled Nucleation Sites

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Solid materials usually contain damage in the form of small voids. If filled with a liquid, these voids can serve as nucleation sites for water to change phase from liquid to gaseous state if sudden pressure changes occur. If the solid structure is subjected to a sudden high-impulse dynamic impact, stress waves are generated and will propagate through the solid and the liquid-filled voids. When subjected to sudden changes in pressure, small bubbles within the liquid-filled voids have the potential to rupture, or cavitate, and emit liquid jets and shockwaves that can increase the damage to the surrounding solid. As the liquid undergoes cavitation, the complex physics of the cavitation bubbles and subsequent jetting will determine how the surrounding solid deforms and breaks. The goal of this research is to use experiments to quantify the resulting deformation in real time with high-speed, non-invasive visualization techniques. The fractured specimens will be post-processed to further evaluate the difference between various scenarios.

If successful, this cross-disciplinary project, integrating fluid mechanics theory with solid mechanics and fracture dynamics, will provide an important step towards understanding the failure modes of solids during highly dynamic short duration tests to assess the strength of structures and lead to viable options to minimize or avoid damage. This project opens new venues for interesting applications, with examples ranging from wave slamming on coastal structures and earthquake impact on dam buildings to non-invasive treatment of kidney stones. This project will support one PhD student at University of Southern California. With focus on promoting the participation of underrepresented groups, undergraduate and high-school students will be invited to work on short-term summer projects related to this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Polymeric materials are often used as the matrix constituent in composite materials that can be utilized in a wide range of outdoor applications, for example, within the naval and aerospace industry. Therefore, it is important to understand how these materials respond to changes in environmental conditions such as temperature, relative humidity, salinity etc. — while at the same time being subjected to sudden or reoccurring highly dynamic loads. In this study, an experimental investigation of dynamic crack initiation and propagation in different types of polymeric test specimens was completed. The specimens were subjected to different types of environmental conditioning resulting in either dry specimens or specimens containing a carefully controlled amount of sorbed water. After the conditioning phase was completed, each specimen was impacted on its edge by a spherical projectile launched from a gas gun. The impact generated a strong enough stress wave inside the sample to induce fracture. To control the site where the fracture occurred, the specimen was prepared with a notch such that the sample would fracture only at the pre-notched site. Quantitative results regarding the crack initiation process and crack propagation were obtained using a combination of a non-invasive optical technique called caustics in transmission and strain gauges attached to the specimens.

Intellectual merit: A new experimental setup was designed and built. The motivation behind this was the need for repeatable impacts so that results from every individual specimen could be compared to the other specimens knowing that the impact loading conditions were the same for all cases. The experimental setup also allowed for specimens to be impacted in dry conditions (ambient air) or while submerged in water. Results were obtained at high strain rates for three different types of materials: PMMA, neat vinyl ester resin, and unidirectional carbon fiber/vinyl ester composites. Results for PMMA showed contradictions to previous results obtained at lower strain rates, thus revealing a strain rate dependent material response. Again, for PMMA, results showed that the crack propagation process was the same no matter if the specimen was impacted while surrounded by air or while submerged in water.

Broader impacts: One latino minority PhD student was trained as part of this project. Upon succesfully completing his PhD degree, this student was also the recipient of two awards; one for the best research assistant in the PI’s Department and another award for excellence in mentoring high school and undergraduate students throughout the length of this project. A number of talks were given by the Principal Investigator (PI), the PhD student, and several of the undergraduate student researchers at various conferences as well as during visits to other universities. As part of the project, the PI and the PhD student also hosted several high school students, both male and female, in the PI’s laboratory during the summers. Four manuscripts have been published to date, and on two of these the coauthors are some of the undergraduate student researchers that worked on this project.

Publications produced as a result of this research:

O. Delpino Gonzales, K. Luong, H. Homma & V. Eliasson, Experimental investigation of dynamic fracture initiation in PMMA submerged in water, Dynamic Behavior of Materials, 2, 391-398. DOI: 10.1007/s40870-016-0074-2, 2016

O. Delpino Gonzales, A.J. Nicassio & V. Eliasson, Evaluation of the effect of water content on the stress optical coefficient in PMMA, Polymer Testing, DOI: 10.1016/j.polymertesting.2016.01.004, 2016

O. Delpino Gonzales & V. Eliasson, Influence of water uptake on dynamic fracture behavior of Poly(methyl methacrylate), Experimental Mechanics, 56 (1), 59-68, DOI:10.1007/s11340-015-0030-4, 2016

O. Delpino Gonzales and V. Eliasson, Effect of water content on dynamic fracture initiation of vinyl ester, Experimental Mechanics, Online first, DOI: 10.1007/s11340-015-0028-y, 2015

Last Modified: 10/27/2016
Modified by: Ivan Bermejo-Moreno

As part of the project, the PI and the PhD student also hosted several high school students, both male and female, in the PI?s laboratory during the summers.
